text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 5.1.18, Locating Taxpayers and their Assets.
5.1.18.4(1) removed the exception relative to the availability of Accurint property records for
IRM 5.1.18.12(3) revised the title of the SB/SE International Coordinator to the SB/SE International Passport Coordinator.
IRM 5.1.18.19.2.3 revised the table to include the authority to request a credit bureau report to aid in collection of the individual liability of a donee or distributee under 31 USC § 3711 (h).
Minor editorial changes have been made throughout this IRM. Website addresses, legal references, and IRM references were reviewed and updated as necessary.
This IRM supersedes IRM 5.1.18 dated August 31, 2018.

) Purpose. This IRM section describes tools and sources Collection can use to locate taxpayers and/or their assets. It also provides procedures and help protect taxpayer privacy when using these sources. (
) Audience. The procedures in this IRM are speciﬁcally intended for use by revenue officers, although other employees in SB/SE and employees in functions may ﬁnd them useful. (
) Policy Owner. SB/SE Director, Collection Policy. (
) Program Owner. SB/SE Collection Policy is the program owner of this IRM. (
) Primary Stakeholders. Field Collection, Civil Enforcement Advice and Operations, Specialty Collection Offers, Specialty Collection Insolvency, and Campus Collection employees. (

) Program Goals. This guidance explains how to research public records in person or online to locate taxpayers and/or their assets. By following the cedures in this IRM, employees will be able to appropriately conduct records searches to locate taxpayers and/or their assets. (

) Contact Information. Recommendations and suggested changes to this should be emailed to the Content Product Owner. The owner is indicated on the Product Catalog Information page which is found on the Forms/Pubs/ Products IRM listing of the Media and Publications website. (
) IRM

, Locating Taxpayers and their Assets, provides guidance and mation for revenue officers. The content includes information on how to the national asset locator tool, real and personal property records, historical travel information, and credit bureau requests. The value and applicability of these taxpayer and asset locator procedures, services and sources depend upon the nature, complexity and the stage of each Collection investigation. (

) Managers are responsible for ensuring that employees have access to the tools needed to perform the job effectively and receive the training required of use the tools appropriately. ) Members of the Functional Automation Support (FAS) groups in Collection tomation Support & Security (CASS) provide training to Collection on how to use software programs that facilitate effective use of the various locator services. (
) FAS also provides technical support and system issues troubleshooting to automated locator service programs and processes. (
) The primary programs supported by FAS include: • Case Diagnostic Tools • Locator Services. (

) Collection Automation Coordinators (CACs) are professional employees who are subject matter experts (SMEs) for the case diagnostic tools and locator services. The CACs responsibilities include the following: • ensure automation programs and management applications are ible with all technical, legal, and administrative provisions • complete analytical reviews • develop reports, memoranda, and decision packages • coordinate and conduct training • act as liaison with other functions at Headquarters, the Areas, and (
) Field Automation Security Coordinators (FASCs) are technical who provide administrative support to the Area CACs. The FASCs ties include the following: • overseeing OL
applications • supporting commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) software. (
) Contact the appropriate Collection Automation Coordinator (CAC) or Field tomation Security Coordinator (FASC) in FAS if you require assistance, support, or training. (
) You can locate the appropriate contact using the Functional Automation Support (CACs, FASS, & FASCs) link who-where.dr/cass/fas.html. (

Functional Automation Support (FAS) provides procurement support for locator services. Generally, the FASC or the CAC is responsible for requisitioning speciﬁc locator services and related equipment. The responsible procurement office will provide any necessary procurement assistance. “Local” contracts may still be required for data that is unavailable from the national contract vehicles.
FAS supports local locator service contracts, such as contracts with the state for employment and DMV information as well as title report contracts. FAS

Field Collecting inputs the annual contract renewals and completes the monthly, quarterly, annual “Receipt and Acceptance.” Some contracts require automation to connect the IRS network to the vendor network. In these cases, FAS tates communication between IT, Mission Assurance, and the end users to ensure the setup, installation, and testing of software when necessary. In cases, based on requests from the Area, FAS will locate new vendors, contracts for services, etc. FAS supports end users on their use of national locator services contracts as well as use of the local contracts. ) Follow the steps below if the information you seek is not reasonably through the contracted subscription search services. a. Use discretion and consider on a case-by-case basis what return infor- mation or PII needs to be entered when using public Internet search engines (for example, name, address, telephone number, or Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number (TIN)). b. A search on a TIN is allowable if necessary, but you must secure gerial approval before conducting an Internet search on a TIN. This approval must be documented in the ICS history. Note: A search on an EIN or an SSN rarely results in any useful tion. A telephone number search will probably provide more information than a TIN search. IRM
, Internet Research, provides that the disclosure of a TIN is sensitive and should be carefully considered. (

) Real property records are a critical source for locating taxpayers and their major assets. Real property records are currently available for all the states and the District of Columbia through the national asset locator tool. the national asset locator tool does not provide an index of transactions or copies of the actual documents. (
) In some states, and especially in large metropolitan areas, the real property records are available electronically from the courthouse without going a third-party vendor (

) Although many real property records are available online, real property are not completely automated. Furthermore, electronic real property may only provide limited coverage and is subject to the following limitations: a. The locator vendor may not provide electronic coverage for every in that state. b. The electronic grantee/grantor indexes may not be sufficient to how ownership in a piece of property occurred or was conveyed. c. The public records data in third-party vendor electronic systems may contain errors due to erroneous data entry or incorrect processing. The data may also be out-dated or be otherwise defective. (

) Some Collection areas have direct database access where courthouse are automated and the index as well as copies of the actual documents are available. Check with your local FAS to see if your area has this capability. See IRM

) All states and the District of Columbia have a department or office of motor vehicles (DMV). DMVs require state residents who own a motor vehicle to register their motor vehicle and require state residents who drive a motor vehicle to hold a valid driver’s license. (
) In addition to driver’s licenses, motor vehicle departments issue (ID) cards to persons who require an ID card. The ID card looks like a license, but it is used for identiﬁcation purposes only. (

) Information maintained by the various DMVs varies from state to state. Most states provide driver information, lien holders, and vehicle information on trucks, etc. ID card information is also provided. (
) Information from

DMVs is currently available through the national asset locator tool at the time of publication of this IRM. Due to contractual and latory restrictions, some states are not available, and it is illegal to make information public in some other states. (
) Some Collection areas have been able to arrange for direct data base to DMV records. Check your local procedures. (

) The United States Postal Service (USPS) provides an address update — the National Change of Address Linkage (NCOALink). Postal (

) The IRS is a licensee of NCOALink, and receives a consolidated data ﬁle with change-of-address information from the USPS on a regular basis to help deliver tax related mail in a timely fashion and reduce undeliverable mail. The Service beneﬁts from the NCOALink address update process by using the addresses to attempt contact and/or maintain contact with taxpayers. (
) When the USPS receives a change of address form from a taxpayer with a new address, the IRS will receive that new address. The process works as follows:
NCOALink obtains change of address information when a taxpayer submits a change of address to the USPS.
The IRS receives a weekly NCOALink ﬁle from USPS. The ﬁle contains of the reported changes of address in the United States for the week.
NCOALink will attempt to match the NCOALink ﬁle to the Master File address for any change of address form ﬁled in the past
months.
The “name” and “from” address must match what is on IDRS for the address to be updated as the new address for a taxpayer.

The Master File is updated for all matched addresses. Note: The only time the address of a taxpayer updates through NCOA Link is the taxpayer submits a change of address form to USPS. Then, and only then, will NCOALink update the taxpayer’s address from one location to another. (
) NCOALink substantially reduces the need for using a postal tracer — Form
, Address Information Request - Postal Tracer, to obtain new addresses for most taxpayers. Note: NCOALink does not eliminate the need for using Form

) Two-line addresses are completely acceptable, but sometimes, we problem with Form

being returned as “not deliverable as addressed” “undeliverable.” This problem is encountered because USPS has high speed equipment (optical character readers) which start reading a of mail from the bottom. The intent of the automated processing is to a piece of mail to its “ﬁnal sort” (practically to the carrier’s mail bag) without ever being touched by human hands. The processing equipment also looks a “match” in the address database. This match depends on a street PO Box to continue on its way. Since we only insert the city, state, and ZIP Code of a particular post office on Form
, the Form
is ejected the automated system and reviewed manually. (

with a two-line address should be delivered to the “Postmaster” at the post office identiﬁed by the Code, a postal worker who sees that Form
does not have a street address or PO Box number may stamp Form

) The Service may obtain passport information from the United States Office in connection with an official investigation. Request a passport check when the taxpayer travels overseas frequently (or there is reason to the taxpayer travels overseas frequently). Requests for information from US Passport Office are called “passport checks.” Passport checks provide formation contained on the most recent passport application ﬁled by a U.S. citizen. The information may include the following : • the last known mailing and/or permanent address of the applicant • applicant’s occupation • applicant’s employer • applicant’s phone number • emergency contact’s name, address and phone number • spouse’s name and birthplace. Note: This information includes the taxpayer’s current address, if available. It includes next of kin information as a third-party source to contact he/she may know the current address of the taxpayer. Caution: A passport check will not provide you with any travel information. If are searching for historical travel information, see IRM
, TECS Historical Travel Information.

) For IRS Collection, TECS provides two sources to help make contact with taxpayers or locate assets: a. Revenue officers can request that delinquent balance due taxpayers be entered into TECS, and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) then advise IRS when those taxpayers travel into the United States for business, employment, or personal reasons. The taxpayers entered into TECS for this purpose are on a TECS lookout indicators list. IRS employees must help maintain the TECS database by requesting that appropriate taxpayers be entered into TECS or be deleted from TECS. (See IRM
for criteria for including taxpayers in TECS database.) b. Revenue officers can also request information housed in TECS on past travel that a taxpayer has made to and from the United States. (

) International and domestic taxpayers can be placed on the TECS lookout indicator list. For domestic taxpayers consideration should be given if it is believed the domestic taxpayer travels frequently outside the U.S. or wealth Territories and contact cannot otherwise be made. Information derived from DHS can facilitate contact with the taxpayer or discovery of asset infor- mation which may facilitate payment of the outstanding liability. (

A revenue officer (RO) requests TECS historical travel information to learn how a taxpayer living in India paid for airline tickets. Up to this point, the RO has not been able to identify any levy sources for this un

cooperative taxpayer. The RO discovers that the payment was made from a bank account in the US. The US bank account is in the name of a family trust. By performing further case investigation, the RO veriﬁes that the family trust is not authentic. The RO coordinates with Advisory and Area Counsel to prepare a transferee assessment which results in collection of part of the balance due. Then the taxpayer contacts the to discuss resolution of the remaining balance.

A revenue officer (RO) requests TECS historical travel information because he/she is unsure where the taxpayer resides. The case currently has an address of record in Florida, but the RO has not been able to contact the taxpayer. The RO believes the taxpayer may often out of the United States. Historical information in the case ﬁle shows the taxpayer once resided in Great Britain. The TECS historical travel infor- mation reveals that the taxpayer visited Canada three times in the last

months. Through subsequent investigation, the RO learns that the taxpayer is now residing permanently in Canada but continues to use the Florida address as a mail drop. This information leads the RO to refer the case for an outgoing Mutual Collection Assistance Request (MCAR) to request assistance from Canada, our treaty partner. The MCAR results in the collection of the outstanding liabilities via levy.

) Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs) are useful tools in tax compliance cases where the taxpayer’s location or banking information is unknown, or when potential fraud indicators point to hidden income or assets. SARs can also reveal indicators that a taxpayer is operating on a cash-basis to avoid income or to evade collection. Examining SARs can open new case avenues to pursue. Compliance employees have successfully used SAR information do the following: • Locate bank accounts opened in the names of deceased relatives • Levy newly-revealed bank accounts, income sources and assets • Contact the taxpayer at a newly-revealed location • Support a nominee lien in an erroneous lien ﬁling suit. (

) Because of the sensitivity and need for careful oversight for access to and of SARs, access will be limited to revenue officers with the type of inventory where a SAR would be most likely to occur and be helpful. See IRM . (

Virtual currency can be held by an administrator or stored in a wallet. A virtual wallet stores the public and private keys and interacts with a blockchain to enable users to send and receive virtual currency and monitor their balance. The public key is a string of alphanumeric characters which functions as an address that the owner provides to receive virtual currency. A private key is a secret (only known to the owner) string of alphanumeric characters or quick reference (QR) codes that provides proof of coin ownership and allows the
owner to send virtual currency to others. A virtual currency wallet is required to conduct a transaction. There are three categories of virtual currency wallets which are described below:

which are described below: • A software wallet is connected to the internet, downloaded, and on a computer or mobile device and stores private keys on the hard drive. • A hardware wallet is a secure offline storage device that stores the user’s ledgers, virtual currency private and public keys. Hardware wallets can be used securely and interactively. They are immune to computer viruses, the keys stored cannot be transferred out of the device in plaintext (unencrypted), and in most instances their software not open source. • A paper wallet is a physical printout of the public and private keys. The user can receive funds by providing the paper wallet’s public address spend funds by providing the private key of the paper wallet or the QR-code to complete the transaction. (

) An exchange is a person or entity engaged in the business of exchanging virtual currency for ﬁat currency, ﬁat for virtual currency, or exchanging other types of virtual currency. Exchanges can be either centralized or (

) A centralized exchange provides a hosted (custodial) wallet service and maintains control over the key pair or address and the assets are under the a commission on transactions and often accept payments by credit card, currency, wire transfers, money orders, and other payment methods. (

) A decentralized exchange relies on an unhosted wallet that is completely trolled by the user. The user is the only party with access to the address required to complete the exchange. The exchange is conducted using the peer-to-peer platform where both parties interact directly with each other. (

) Virtual currency may be identiﬁed through normal collection investigative niques which include interviews, bank or credit card analysis, summons and investigations with available programs (e.g. IDRS or Fi
EN). (

) ROs may identify virtual currency transactions during taxpayer interviews. While interviewing the taxpayer to secure a Collection Information Statement (CIS) inquire about ownership in other investments like virtual currency (e.g. Bitcoin, Ripple, or Litecoin). (

) ROs may also recognize virtual currency transactions while conducting a or credit card statement analysis by recognizing transactions conducted with exchanges or references to speciﬁc virtual currency. Also, a review of previ- ously ﬁled income tax returns may identify gains or losses related to virtual currency. (

) Merchants often accept payment of virtual currency. Businesses that accept virtual currency may have a QR code near the cash register or advertise the type of virtual currency accepted on their business website. IDRS command code (cc) IRPTR will provide Form

5.1.18.20.3 (07-17-2019) Identifying Virtual Currency
) Summonsing a centralized exchange will often provide information on linked ﬁnancial institutions, credit cards, or investment accounts that are used to conduct virtual currency transactions. (
) Fi
EN Query reports are ﬁled by money service businesses and may identify participation in virtual currency transactions. Fi
EN Query reports also contain SARs that are ﬁled by other ﬁnancial institutions regarding excessive virtual currency transactions conducted within a short time frame. (

) An internet search of the blockchain requires the user to know the public key address to analyze transactions conducted using the address. The public key address can be researched to determine the total transactions conducted, type of transactions (sent or received), and the remaining balance of virtual currency units. Researching blockchain transactions will seldom reveal the identiﬁcation of the participants conducting the transactions.

Exhibit 5.1.18-2 (06-10-2015) Procedures for Authorized Users to Obtain FCQ Reports

Abusive Tax Avoidance Transaction (ATAT), International and Grade 13 ROs are authorized access to FCQ in- formation in connection with active and assigned cases. In order to be proﬁled to access the FCQ system, ROs must complete all required training. (See Exhibit 5.1.18-3 for more details.)

Authorized Users have the ability to select from one of four search options and use enhancements, such as ﬁlters, wildcards, operators and import lists, to facilitate search efforts. ROs can refer to the FCQ User Manual for guidance in interpreting FCQ extracts at: FinCENQueryUserManual1.pdf.
The following prerequisites are required prior to granting access to the FCQ system:
Safeguarding, Requesting & Using Suspicious Activity Report (SAR) Security (ELMS #36427) Safeguarding Online Access and Using Suspicious Activity Report (SAR) Info Brieﬁng (ELMS

Exhibit 5.1.18-4 (06-10-2015) BSA Review Procedures for Managers

Collection managers of employees with electronic access to BSA information must conduct online reviews of the FinCEN audit trails at least annually. Collection managers with ATAT or Grade 13 ROs are responsible for con- ducting reviews on their employees. The IDRS Data Security Staff is responsible for conducting reviews on FAS employees. The audits must include all FCQ searches within a selected 30 day period within the past year. BSA will provide an audit trail report, which is a history of the query parameters used by the FCQ user. The system will maintain 13 months of user query information.
BSA has established a FinCEN Query audit report mailbox to use when requesting audit trail information on speciﬁc FCQ system users. The mailbox address is: *SBSE FCQ AUDIT TRAIL

When managers or data security analysts need an audit trail report for a FCQ user, they send the full employee email address and the period of the audit trail request using the above mailbox address. Multiple FCQ user audit trails can be included in each email request.

BSA will send the requested audit trail information directly to the requestor through secure email. Managers or data security analysts should contact their FCQ administrators for speciﬁc audit trail requirements beyond the basics we have outlined here.
